Thus, to determine a therapeutic window for the electroporation procedure, the voltage intensity was gradually diminished and the corresponding muscle damage assessed as previously (Fig 7).

In an attempt to assess the therapeutic window of the adenoviral vector in this poorly permissive tumour, the number of transduced cells in the tumour was determined by injection of vectors encoding the ?-galactosidase gene (Table 1).
In contrast to intramuscular delivery, the electroporation of tumours seems to offer a wider therapeutic window.
Thus, to determine a therapeutic window for the electroporation procedure, the voltage intensity was gradually diminished and the corresponding muscle damage assessed as previously (Fig 7).
Unfortunately the luciferase expression levels decreased as fast as the muscle damage, and no therapeutic window could be found with these settings.

(TNO-Prevention and Health, Leiden The Netherlands), using a monoclonal antibody specific for the ATF as the capture antibody and a polyclonal antibody directed against BPTI as the detector antibody [ 24 ] . As a standard we used either urokinase or mhATF-BPTI.
Thus, there is strong evidence that muscle electroporation, as it usually performed, is severely damaging and reduces plasmid expression to the survival cells.
In case of tumours that are poorly permissive to adenovirus, it is difficult to transduce a large number of tumour cells with adenoviral vectors without inducing severe liver damage.
Microscopic examination revealed severe muscle necrosis (fig 5) that was accompanied by a severe polynuclear eosinophilic and mast cell infiltration.

The toxicity of these vectors is well documented [ 6 5 ] . Systemic delivery of adenovirus vectors induces mild liver damage at low dose (10 9iu in mice) and severe hepatitis and bone marrow necrosis at high dose (10 11iu in a mice).

More importantly, the electric pulse delivery caused on its own a severe rhabdomyolysis and the prior injection of saline significantly increased the muscle damage, but the addition of naked DNA did not influence the muscle injury.

Intramuscular injection of 10 10iu induces moderate local inflammation [ 15 ] . However, the local and systemic toxicity of the adenoviruses can be dramatically reduced by using gutless viruses [ 16 ] . Notably, we observed severe muscle damage after the electric pulse delivery, which was worsened by the pre injection of saline but was not influenced by the presence of plasmid.
Microscopic examination revealed severe muscle necrosis (fig 5) that was accompanied by a severe polynuclear eosinophilic and mast cell infiltration.

More importantly, the electric pulse delivery caused on its own a severe rhabdomyolysis and the prior injection of saline significantly increased the muscle damage, but the addition of naked DNA did not influence the muscle injury.
Since the creatine kinase levels are not decreasing within the first week after electroporation, the muscle lesions must have continued over several days.
Unfortunately the luciferase expression levels decreased as fast as the muscle damage, and no therapeutic window could be found with these settings.

The plasmid pAdapt Luc, pAdpat LacZ, pAdapt hEndo and pAdapt mhAB encoding respectively for the luciferase, ?-galactosidase, human endostatine and murinised human ATF-BPTI genes were constructed as described previously [ 23 ] . The different genes are under the control of the cytomegalovirus (CMV) immediate-early promotor and terminated by the simian virus (SV40) late poly(A) signal.
Different positions of the leg between the electrodes were tested with no influence on the toxicity.
Different positions of the leg between the electrodes were tested with no influence on the toxicity.
Different positions of the leg between the electrodes were tested with no influence on the toxicity.
The surface measurements were performed with the NIH Image 1.62 software.

have made attempts to improve the electroporation protocol by introducing new settings, consisting in the combination of high voltage and low voltages pulses, that are inducing less permeabilisation of the myocytes [ 22 ] . Even if these combined protocols seems to be slightly less toxic, there is still much improvement needed to compete with the new generations of adenoviral vectors as a method to transfect muscle in patients.

The possible damage induced by the electroporation could not be easily determined due to the high background of necrosis in the tumour tissue, but if it occurs it could only add to the therapeutic effect.
have shown that increasing the dose from 30 ?g to 300 ?g by multiple injections resulted in 7 to 10 fold higher plasma levels.
The lesions described by these authors and us have much in common with those induced by electrocution chocks.
Similar damage occurred after using a simple anaesthesia (hypnorm) or in combination with muscle relaxants during electroporation.

have made attempts to improve the electroporation protocol by introducing new settings, consisting in the combination of high voltage and low voltages pulses, that are inducing less permeabilisation of the myocytes [ 22 ] . Even if these combined protocols seems to be slightly less toxic, there is still much improvement needed to compete with the new generations of adenoviral vectors as a method to transfect muscle in patients.
